table.name: acquisition
table.remarks: This represents the scanning of hybridized material. The output of this process is typically a digital image of an array.

table.name: acquisition_relationship
table.remarks: Multiple monochrome images may be merged to form a multi-color image. Red-green images of 2-channel hybridizations are an example of this.

table.name: acquisitionprop
table.remarks: Parameters associated with image acquisition.

table.name: analysis
table.remarks: An analysis is a particular type of a computational analysis; it may be a blast of one sequence against another, or an all by all blast, or a different kind of analysis altogether. It is a single unit of computation.

column.name: name
column.remarks: A way of grouping analyses. This should be a handy short identifier that can help people find an analysis they want. For instance "tRNAscan", "cDNA", "FlyPep", "SwissProt", and it should not be assumed to be unique. For instance, there may be lots of separate analyses done against a cDNA database.

column.name: program
column.remarks: Program name, e.g. blastx, blastp, sim4, genscan.

column.name: programversion
column.remarks: Version description, e.g. TBLASTX 2.0MP-WashU [09-Nov-2000].

column.name: algorithm
column.remarks: Algorithm name, e.g. blast.

column.name: sourcename
column.remarks: Source name, e.g. cDNA, SwissProt.

column.name: sourceuri
column.remarks: This is an optional, permanent URL or URI for the source of the analysis. The idea is that someone could recreate the analysis directly by going to this URI and fetching the source data (e.g. the blast database, or the training model).

table.name: analysis_cvterm
table.remarks: Associate a term from a cv with an analysis.

column.name: is_not
column.remarks: If this is set to true, then this annotation is interpreted as a NEGATIVE annotation - i.e. the analysis does NOT have the specified term.

table.name: analysis_dbxref
table.remarks: Links an analysis to dbxrefs.

column.name: is_current
column.remarks: True if this dbxref is the most up to date accession in the corresponding db. Retired accessions should set this field to false

table.name: analysis_pub
table.remarks: Provenance. Linking table between analyses and the publications that mention them.

column.name: subject_id
column.remarks: analysis_relationship.subject_id i s the subject of the subj-predicate-obj sentence.

column.name: object_id
column.remarks: analysis_relationship.object_id is the object of the subj-predicate-obj sentence.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: analysis_relationship.type_id is relationship type between subject and object. This is a cvterm, typically from the OBO relationship ontology, although other relationship types are allowed.

column.name: value
column.remarks: analysis_relationship.value is for additional notes or comments.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: analysis_relationship.rank is the ordering of subject analysiss with respect to the object analysis may be important where rank is used to order these; starts from zero.

table.name: analysisfeature
table.remarks: Computational analyses generate features (e.g. Genscan generates transcripts and exons; sim4 alignments generate similarity/match features). analysisfeatures are stored using the feature table from the sequence module. The analysisfeature table is used to decorate these features, with analysis specific attributes. A feature is an analysisfeature if and only if there is a corresponding entry in the analysisfeature table. analysisfeatures will have two or more featureloc entries, with rank indicating query/subject

column.name: rawscore
column.remarks: This is the native score generated by the program; for example, the bitscore generated by blast, sim4 or genscan scores. One should not assume that high is necessarily better than low.

column.name: normscore
column.remarks: This is the rawscore but semi-normalized. Complete normalization to allow comparison of features generated by different programs would be nice but too difficult. Instead the normalization should strive to enforce the following semantics: * normscores are floating point numbers >= 0, * high normscores are better than low one. For most programs, it would be sufficient to make the normscore the same as this rawscore, providing these semantics are satisfied.

column.name: significance
column.remarks: This is some kind of expectation or probability metric, representing the probability that the analysis would appear randomly given the model. As such, any program or person querying this table can assume the following semantics: * 0 <= significance <= n, where n is a positive number, theoretically unbounded but unlikely to be more than 10 * low numbers are better than high numbers.

column.name: identity
column.remarks: Percent identity between the locations compared. Note that these 4 metrics do not cover the full range of scores possible; it would be undesirable to list every score possible, as this should be kept extensible. instead, for non-standard scores, use the analysisprop table.

table.name: arraydesign
table.remarks: General properties about an array. An array is a template used to generate physical slides, etc. It contains layout information, as well as global array properties, such as material (glass, nylon) and spot dimensions (in rows/columns).

table.name: arraydesignprop
table.remarks: Extra array design properties that are not accounted for in arraydesign.

table.name: assay
table.remarks: An assay consists of a physical instance of an array, combined with the conditions used to create the array (protocols, technician information). The assay can be thought of as a hybridization.

table.name: assay_biomaterial
table.remarks: A biomaterial can be hybridized many times (technical replicates), or combined with other biomaterials in a single hybridization (for two-channel arrays).

table.name: assay_project
table.remarks: Link assays to projects.

table.name: assayprop
table.remarks: Extra assay properties that are not accounted for in assay.

table.name: biomaterial
table.remarks: A biomaterial represents the MAGE concept of BioSource, BioSample, and LabeledExtract. It is essentially some biological material (tissue, cells, serum) that may have been processed. Processed biomaterials should be traceable back to raw biomaterials via the biomaterialrelationship table.

table.name: biomaterial_relationship
table.remarks: Relate biomaterials to one another. This is a way to track a series of treatments or material splits/merges, for instance.

table.name: biomaterial_treatment
table.remarks: Link biomaterials to treatments. Treatments have an order of operations (rank), and associated measurements (unittype_id, value).

table.name: biomaterialprop
table.remarks: Extra biomaterial properties that are not accounted for in biomaterial.

table.name: chadoprop
table.remarks: This table is different from other prop tables in the database, as it is for storing information about the database itself, like schema version

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The name of the property or slot is a cvterm. The meaning of the property is defined in that cvterm.

column.name: value
column.remarks: The value of the property, represented as text. Numeric values are converted to their text representation.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: Property-Value ordering. Any cv can have multiple values for any particular property type - these are ordered in a list using rank, counting from zero. For properties that are single-valued rather than multi-valued, the default 0 value should be used.

table.name: channel
table.remarks: Different array platforms can record signals from one or more channels (cDNA arrays typically use two CCD, but Affymetrix uses only one).

table.name: contact
table.remarks: Model persons, institutes, groups, organizations, etc.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: What type of contact is this? E.g. "person", "lab".

table.name: contact_relationship
table.remarks: Model relationships between contacts

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: Relationship type between subject and object. This is a cvterm, typically from the OBO relationship ontology, although other relationship types are allowed.

column.name: subject_id
column.remarks: The subject of the subj-predicate-obj sentence. In a DAG, this corresponds to the child node.

column.name: object_id
column.remarks: The object of the subj-predicate-obj sentence. In a DAG, this corresponds to the parent node.

table.name: contactprop
table.remarks: A contact can have any number of slot-value property tags attached to it. This is an alternative to hardcoding a list of columns in the relational schema, and is completely extensible.

table.name: cv
table.remarks: A controlled vocabulary or ontology. A cv is composed of cvterms (AKA terms, classes, types, universals - relations and properties are also stored in cvterm) and the relationships between them.

column.name: name
column.remarks: The name of the ontology. This corresponds to the obo-format -namespace-. cv names uniquely identify the cv. In OBO file format, the cv.name is known as the namespace.

column.name: definition
column.remarks: A text description of the criteria for membership of this ontology.

table.name: cvprop
table.remarks: Additional extensible properties can be attached to a cv using this table. A notable example would be the cv version

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The name of the property or slot is a cvterm. The meaning of the property is defined in that cvterm.

column.name: value
column.remarks: The value of the property, represented as text. Numeric values are converted to their text representation.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: Property-Value ordering. Any cv can have multiple values for any particular property type - these are ordered in a list using rank, counting from zero. For properties that are single-valued rather than multi-valued, the default 0 value should be used.

table.name: cvterm
table.remarks: A term, class, universal or type within an ontology or controlled vocabulary. This table is also used for relations and properties. cvterms constitute nodes in the graph defined by the collection of cvterms and cvterm_relationships.

column.name: cv_id
column.remarks: The cv or ontology or namespace to which this cvterm belongs.

column.name: name
column.remarks: A concise human-readable name or label for the cvterm. Uniquely identifies a cvterm within a cv.

column.name: definition
column.remarks: A human-readable text definition.

column.name: dbxref_id
column.remarks: Primary identifier dbxref - The unique global OBO identifier for this cvterm. Note that a cvterm may have multiple secondary dbxrefs - see also table: cvterm_dbxref.

column.name: is_obsolete
column.remarks: Boolean 0=false,1=true; see GO documentation for details of obsoletion. Note that two terms with different primary dbxrefs may exist if one is obsolete.

column.name: is_relationshiptype
column.remarks: Boolean 0=false,1=true relations or relationship types (also known as Typedefs in OBO format, or as properties or slots) form a cv/ontology in themselves. We use this flag to indicate whether this cvterm is an actual term/class/universal or a relation. Relations may be drawn from the OBO Relations ontology, but are not exclusively drawn from there.

table.name: cvterm_dbxref
table.remarks: In addition to the primary identifier (cvterm.dbxref_id) a cvterm can have zero or more secondary identifiers/dbxrefs, which may refer to records in external databases. The exact semantics of cvterm_dbxref are not fixed. For example: the dbxref could be a pubmed ID that is pertinent to the cvterm, or it could be an equivalent or similar term in another ontology. For example, GO cvterms are typically linked to InterPro IDs, even though the nature of the relationship between them is largely one of statistical association. The dbxref may be have data records attached in the same database instance, or it could be a "hanging" dbxref pointing to some external database. NOTE: If the desired objective is to link two cvterms together, and the nature of the relation is known and holds for all instances of the subject cvterm then consider instead using cvterm_relationship together with a well-defined relation.

column.name: is_for_definition
column.remarks: A cvterm.definition should be supported by one or more references. If this column is true, the dbxref is not for a term in an external database - it is a dbxref for provenance information for the definition.

table.name: cvterm_relationship
table.remarks: A relationship linking two cvterms. Each cvterm_relationship constitutes an edge in the graph defined by the collection of cvterms and cvterm_relationships. The meaning of the cvterm_relationship depends on the definition of the cvterm R refered to by type_id. However, in general the definitions are such that the statement "all SUBJs REL some OBJ" is true. The cvterm_relationship statement is about the subject, not the object. For example "insect wing part_of thorax".

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The nature of the relationship between subject and object. Note that relations are also housed in the cvterm table, typically from the OBO relationship ontology, although other relationship types are allowed.

column.name: subject_id
column.remarks: The subject of the subj-predicate-obj sentence. The cvterm_relationship is about the subject. In a graph, this typically corresponds to the child node.

column.name: object_id
column.remarks: The object of the subj-predicate-obj sentence. The cvterm_relationship refers to the object. In a graph, this typically corresponds to the parent node.

table.name: cvtermpath
table.remarks: The reflexive transitive closure of the cvterm_relationship relation.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The relationship type that this is a closure over. If null, then this is a closure over ALL relationship types. If non-null, then this references a relationship cvterm - note that the closure will apply to both this relationship AND the OBO_REL:is_a (subclass) relationship.

column.name: cv_id
column.remarks: Closures will mostly be within one cv. If the closure of a relationship traverses a cv, then this refers to the cv of the object_id cvterm.

column.name: pathdistance
column.remarks: The number of steps required to get from the subject cvterm to the object cvterm, counting from zero (reflexive relationship).

table.name: cvtermprop
table.remarks: Additional extensible properties can be attached to a cvterm using this table. Corresponds to -AnnotationProperty- in W3C OWL format.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The name of the property or slot is a cvterm. The meaning of the property is defined in that cvterm.

column.name: value
column.remarks: The value of the property, represented as text. Numeric values are converted to their text representation.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: Property-Value ordering. Any cvterm can have multiple values for any particular property type - these are ordered in a list using rank, counting from zero. For properties that are single-valued rather than multi-valued, the default 0 value should be used.

table.name: cvtermsynonym
table.remarks: A cvterm actually represents a distinct class or concept. A concept can be refered to by different phrases or names. In addition to the primary name (cvterm.name) there can be a number of alternative aliases or synonyms. For example, "T cell" as a synonym for "T lymphocyte".

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: A synonym can be exact, narrower, or broader than.

table.name: db
table.remarks: A database authority. Typical databases in bioinformatics are FlyBase, GO, UniProt, NCBI, MGI, etc. The authority is generally known by this shortened form, which is unique within the bioinformatics and biomedical realm. To Do - add support for URIs, URNs (e.g. LSIDs). We can do this by treating the URL as a URI - however, some applications may expect this to be resolvable - to be decided.

table.name: dbprop
table.remarks: An external database can have any number of slot-value property tags attached to it. This is an alternative to hardcoding a list of columns in the relational schema, and is completely extensible. There is a unique constraint, dbprop_c1, for the combination of db_id, rank, and type_id. Multivalued property-value pairs must be differentiated by rank.

table.name: dbxref
table.remarks: A unique, global, public, stable identifier. Not necessarily an external reference - can reference data items inside the particular chado instance being used. Typically a row in a table can be uniquely identified with a primary identifier (called dbxref_id); a table may also have secondary identifiers (in a linking table <T>_dbxref). A dbxref is generally written as <DB>:<ACCESSION> or as <DB>:<ACCESSION>:<VERSION>.

column.name: accession
column.remarks: The local part of the identifier. Guaranteed by the db authority to be unique for that db.

table.name: dbxrefprop
table.remarks: Metadata about a dbxref. Note that this is not defined in the dbxref module, as it depends on the cvterm table. This table has a structure analagous to cvtermprop.

column.name: eimage_data
column.remarks: We expect images in eimage_data (e.g. JPEGs) to be uuencoded.

column.name: eimage_type
column.remarks: Describes the type of data in eimage_data.

table.name: element
table.remarks: Represents a feature of the array. This is typically a region of the array coated or bound to DNA.

table.name: element_relationship
table.remarks: Sometimes we want to combine measurements from multiple elements to get a composite value. Affymetrix combines many probes to form a probeset measurement, for instance.

table.name: elementresult
table.remarks: An element on an array produces a measurement when hybridized to a biomaterial (traceable through quantification_id). This is the base data from which tables that actually contain data inherit.

table.name: elementresult_relationship
table.remarks: Sometimes we want to combine measurements from multiple elements to get a composite value. Affymetrix combines many probes to form a probeset measurement, for instance.

table.name: environment
table.remarks: The environmental component of a phenotype description.

table.name: expression
table.remarks: The expression table is essentially a bridge table.

table.name: expression_cvtermprop
table.remarks: Extensible properties for expression to cvterm associations. Examples: qualifiers.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The name of the property/slot is a cvterm. The meaning of the property is defined in that cvterm. For example, cvterms may come from the FlyBase miscellaneous cv.

column.name: value
column.remarks: The value of the property, represented as text. Numeric values are converted to their text representation. This is less efficient than using native database types, but is easier to query.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: Property-Value ordering. Any expression_cvterm can have multiple values for any particular property type - these are ordered in a list using rank, counting from zero. For properties that are single-valued rather than multi-valued, the default 0 value should be used.

table.name: feature
table.remarks: A feature is a biological sequence or a section of a biological sequence, or a collection of such sections. Examples include genes, exons, transcripts, regulatory regions, polypeptides, protein domains, chromosome sequences, sequence variations, cross-genome match regions such as hits and HSPs and so on; see the Sequence Ontology for more. The combination of organism_id, uniquename and type_id should be unique.

column.name: dbxref_id
column.remarks: An optional primary public stable identifier for this feature. Secondary identifiers and external dbxrefs go in the table feature_dbxref.

column.name: organism_id
column.remarks: The organism to which this feature belongs. This column is mandatory.

column.name: name
column.remarks: The optional human-readable common name for a feature, for display purposes.

column.name: uniquename
column.remarks: The unique name for a feature; may not be necessarily be particularly human-readable, although this is preferred. This name must be unique for this type of feature within this organism.

column.name: residues
column.remarks: A sequence of alphabetic characters representing biological residues (nucleic acids, amino acids). This column does not need to be manifested for all features; it is optional for features such as exons where the residues can be derived from the featureloc. It is recommended that the value for this column be manifested for features which may may non-contiguous sublocations (e.g. transcripts), since derivation at query time is non-trivial. For expressed sequence, the DNA sequence should be used rather than the RNA sequence. The default storage method for the residues column is EXTERNAL, which will store it uncompressed to make substring operations faster.

column.name: seqlen
column.remarks: The length of the residue feature. See column:residues. This column is partially redundant with the residues column, and also with featureloc. This column is required because the location may be unknown and the residue sequence may not be manifested, yet it may be desirable to store and query the length of the feature. The seqlen should always be manifested where the length of the sequence is known.

column.name: md5checksum
column.remarks: The 32-character checksum of the sequence, calculated using the MD5 algorithm. This is practically guaranteed to be unique for any feature. This column thus acts as a unique identifier on the mathematical sequence.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: A required reference to a table:cvterm giving the feature type. This will typically be a Sequence Ontology identifier. This column is thus used to subclass the feature table.

column.name: is_analysis
column.remarks: Boolean indicating whether this feature is annotated or the result of an automated analysis. Analysis results also use the companalysis module. Note that the dividing line between analysis and annotation may be fuzzy, this should be determined on a per-project basis in a consistent manner. One requirement is that there should only be one non-analysis version of each wild-type gene feature in a genome, whereas the same gene feature can be predicted multiple times in different analyses.

column.name: is_obsolete
column.remarks: Boolean indicating whether this feature has been obsoleted. Some chado instances may choose to simply remove the feature altogether, others may choose to keep an obsolete row in the table.

column.name: timeaccessioned
column.remarks: For handling object accession or modification timestamps (as opposed to database auditing data, handled elsewhere). The expectation is that these fields would be available to software interacting with chado.

column.name: timelastmodified
column.remarks: For handling object accession or modification timestamps (as opposed to database auditing data, handled elsewhere). The expectation is that these fields would be available to software interacting with chado.

table.name: feature_contact
table.remarks: Links contact(s) with a feature. Used to indicate a particular person or organization responsible for discovery or that can provide more information on a particular feature.

table.name: feature_cvterm
table.remarks: Associate a term from a cv with a feature, for example, GO annotation.

column.name: pub_id
column.remarks: Provenance for the annotation. Each annotation should have a single primary publication (which may be of the appropriate type for computational analyses) where more details can be found. Additional provenance dbxrefs can be attached using feature_cvterm_dbxref.

column.name: is_not
column.remarks: If this is set to true, then this annotation is interpreted as a NEGATIVE annotation - i.e. the feature does NOT have the specified function, process, component, part, etc. See GO docs for more details.

table.name: feature_cvterm_dbxref
table.remarks: Additional dbxrefs for an association. Rows in the feature_cvterm table may be backed up by dbxrefs. For example, a feature_cvterm association that was inferred via a protein-protein interaction may be backed by by refering to the dbxref for the alternate protein. Corresponds to the WITH column in a GO gene association file (but can also be used for other analagous associations). See http://www.geneontology.org/doc/GO.annotation.shtml#file for more details.

table.name: feature_cvterm_pub
table.remarks: Secondary pubs for an association. Each feature_cvterm association is supported by a single primary publication. Additional secondary pubs can be added using this linking table (in a GO gene association file, these corresponding to any IDs after the pipe symbol in the publications column.

table.name: feature_cvtermprop
table.remarks: Extensible properties for feature to cvterm associations. Examples: GO evidence codes; qualifiers; metadata such as the date on which the entry was curated and the source of the association. See the featureprop table for meanings of type_id, value and rank.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The name of the property/slot is a cvterm. The meaning of the property is defined in that cvterm. cvterms may come from the OBO evidence code cv.

column.name: value
column.remarks: The value of the property, represented as text. Numeric values are converted to their text representation. This is less efficient than using native database types, but is easier to query.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: Property-Value ordering. Any feature_cvterm can have multiple values for any particular property type - these are ordered in a list using rank, counting from zero. For properties that are single-valued rather than multi-valued, the default 0 value should be used.

table.name: feature_dbxref
table.remarks: Links a feature to dbxrefs.

column.name: is_current
column.remarks: True if this secondary dbxref is the most up to date accession in the corresponding db. Retired accessions should set this field to false

table.name: feature_expressionprop
table.remarks: Extensible properties for feature_expression (comments, for example). Modeled on feature_cvtermprop.

column.name: chromosome_id
column.remarks: A feature of SO type "chromosome".

column.name: rank
column.remarks: rank can be used for n-ploid organisms or to preserve order.

column.name: cgroup
column.remarks: Spatially distinguishable group. group can be used for distinguishing the chromosomal groups, for example (RNAi products and so on can be treated as different groups, as they do not fall on a particular chromosome).

table.name: feature_phenotype
table.remarks: Linking table between features and phenotypes.

table.name: feature_pub
table.remarks: Provenance. Linking table between features and publications that mention them.

table.name: feature_pubprop
table.remarks: Property or attribute of a feature_pub link.

table.name: feature_relationship
table.remarks: Features can be arranged in graphs, e.g. "exon part_of transcript part_of gene"; If type is thought of as a verb, the each arc or edge makes a statement [Subject Verb Object]. The object can also be thought of as parent (containing feature), and subject as child (contained feature or subfeature). We include the relationship rank/order, because even though most of the time we can order things implicitly by sequence coordinates, we can not always do this - e.g. transpliced genes. It is also useful for quickly getting implicit introns.

column.name: subject_id
column.remarks: The subject of the subj-predicate-obj sentence. This is typically the subfeature.

column.name: object_id
column.remarks: The object of the subj-predicate-obj sentence. This is typically the container feature.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: Relationship type between subject and object. This is a cvterm, typically from the OBO relationship ontology, although other relationship types are allowed. The most common relationship type is OBO_REL:part_of. Valid relationship types are constrained by the Sequence Ontology.

column.name: value
column.remarks: Additional notes or comments.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: The ordering of subject features with respect to the object feature may be important (for example, exon ordering on a transcript - not always derivable if you take trans spliced genes into consideration). Rank is used to order these; starts from zero.

table.name: feature_relationship_pub
table.remarks: Provenance. Attach optional evidence to a feature_relationship in the form of a publication.

table.name: feature_relationshipprop
table.remarks: Extensible properties for feature_relationships. Analagous structure to featureprop. This table is largely optional and not used with a high frequency. Typical scenarios may be if one wishes to attach additional data to a feature_relationship - for example to say that the feature_relationship is only true in certain contexts.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The name of the property/slot is a cvterm. The meaning of the property is defined in that cvterm. Currently there is no standard ontology for feature_relationship property types.

column.name: value
column.remarks: The value of the property, represented as text. Numeric values are converted to their text representation. This is less efficient than using native database types, but is easier to query.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: Property-Value ordering. Any feature_relationship can have multiple values for any particular property type - these are ordered in a list using rank, counting from zero. For properties that are single-valued rather than multi-valued, the default 0 value should be used.

table.name: feature_relationshipprop_pub
table.remarks: Provenance for feature_relationshipprop.

table.name: feature_synonym
table.remarks: Linking table between feature and synonym.

column.name: pub_id
column.remarks: The pub_id link is for relating the usage of a given synonym to the publication in which it was used.

column.name: is_current
column.remarks: The is_current boolean indicates whether the linked synonym is the current -official- symbol for the linked feature.

column.name: is_internal
column.remarks: Typically a synonym exists so that somebody querying the db with an obsolete name can find the object theyre looking for (under its current name. If the synonym has been used publicly and deliberately (e.g. in a paper), it may also be listed in reports as a synonym. If the synonym was not used deliberately (e.g. there was a typo which went public), then the is_internal boolean may be set to -true- so that it is known that the synonym is -internal- and should be queryable but should not be listed in reports as a valid synonym.

table.name: featureloc
table.remarks: The location of a feature relative to another feature. Important: interbase coordinates are used. This is vital as it allows us to represent zero-length features e.g. splice sites, insertion points without an awkward fuzzy system. Features typically have exactly ONE location, but this need not be the case. Some features may not be localized (e.g. a gene that has been characterized genetically but no sequence or molecular information is available). Note on multiple locations: Each feature can have 0 or more locations. Multiple locations do NOT indicate non-contiguous locations (if a feature such as a transcript has a non-contiguous location, then the subfeatures such as exons should always be manifested). Instead, multiple featurelocs for a feature designate alternate locations or grouped locations; for instance, a feature designating a blast hit or hsp will have two locations, one on the query feature, one on the subject feature. Features representing sequence variation could have alternate locations instantiated on a feature on the mutant strain. The column:rank is used to differentiate these different locations. Reflexive locations should never be stored - this is for -proper- (i.e. non-self) locations only; nothing should be located relative to itself.

column.name: feature_id
column.remarks: The feature that is being located. Any feature can have zero or more featurelocs.

column.name: srcfeature_id
column.remarks: The source feature which this location is relative to. Every location is relative to another feature (however, this column is nullable, because the srcfeature may not be known). All locations are -proper- that is, nothing should be located relative to itself. No cycles are allowed in the featureloc graph.

column.name: fmin
column.remarks: The leftmost/minimal boundary in the linear range represented by the featureloc. Sometimes (e.g. in Bioperl) this is called -start- although this is confusing because it does not necessarily represent the 5-prime coordinate. Important: This is space-based (interbase) coordinates, counting from zero. To convert this to the leftmost position in a base-oriented system (eg GFF, Bioperl), add 1 to fmin.

column.name: is_fmin_partial
column.remarks: This is typically false, but may be true if the value for column:fmin is inaccurate or the leftmost part of the range is unknown/unbounded.

column.name: fmax
column.remarks: The rightmost/maximal boundary in the linear range represented by the featureloc. Sometimes (e.g. in bioperl) this is called -end- although this is confusing because it does not necessarily represent the 3-prime coordinate. Important: This is space-based (interbase) coordinates, counting from zero. No conversion is required to go from fmax to the rightmost coordinate in a base-oriented system that counts from 1 (e.g. GFF, Bioperl).

column.name: is_fmax_partial
column.remarks: This is typically false, but may be true if the value for column:fmax is inaccurate or the rightmost part of the range is unknown/unbounded.

column.name: strand
column.remarks: The orientation/directionality of the location. Should be 0, -1 or +1.

column.name: phase
column.remarks: Phase of translation with respect to srcfeature_id. Values are 0, 1, 2. It may not be possible to manifest this column for some features such as exons, because the phase is dependant on the spliceform (the same exon can appear in multiple spliceforms). This column is mostly useful for predicted exons and CDSs.

column.name: residue_info
column.remarks: Alternative residues, when these differ from feature.residues. For instance, a SNP feature located on a wild and mutant protein would have different alternative residues. for alignment/similarity features, the alternative residues is used to represent the alignment string (CIGAR format). Note on variation features; even if we do not want to instantiate a mutant chromosome/contig feature, we can still represent a SNP etc with 2 locations, one (rank 0) on the genome, the other (rank 1) would have most fields null, except for alternative residues.

column.name: locgroup
column.remarks: This is used to manifest redundant, derivable extra locations for a feature. The default locgroup=0 is used for the DIRECT location of a feature. Important: most Chado users may never use featurelocs WITH logroup > 0. Transitively derived locations are indicated with locgroup > 0. For example, the position of an exon on a BAC and in global chromosome coordinates. This column is used to differentiate these groupings of locations. The default locgroup 0 is used for the main or primary location, from which the others can be derived via coordinate transformations. Another example of redundant locations is storing ORF coordinates relative to both transcript and genome. Redundant locations open the possibility of the database getting into inconsistent states; this schema gives us the flexibility of both warehouse instantiations with redundant locations (easier for querying) and management instantiations with no redundant locations. An example of using both locgroup and rank: imagine a feature indicating a conserved region between the chromosomes of two different species. We may want to keep redundant locations on both contigs and chromosomes. We would thus have 4 locations for the single conserved region feature - two distinct locgroups (contig level and chromosome level) and two distinct ranks (for the two species).

column.name: rank
column.remarks: Used when a feature has >1 location, otherwise the default rank 0 is used. Some features (e.g. blast hits and HSPs) have two locations - one on the query and one on the subject. Rank is used to differentiate these. Rank=0 is always used for the query, Rank=1 for the subject. For multiple alignments, assignment of rank is arbitrary. Rank is also used for sequence_variant features, such as SNPs. Rank=0 indicates the wildtype (or baseline) feature, Rank=1 indicates the mutant (or compared) feature.

table.name: featureloc_pub
table.remarks: Provenance of featureloc. Linking table between featurelocs and publications that mention them.

table.name: featuremap_contact
table.remarks: Links contact(s) with a featuremap. Used to indicate a particular person or organization responsible for constrution of or that can provide more information on a particular featuremap.

table.name: featuremap_organism
table.remarks: Links a featuremap to the organism(s) with which it is associated.

table.name: featuremapprop
table.remarks: A featuremap can have any number of slot-value property tags attached to it. This is an alternative to hardcoding a list of columns in the relational schema, and is completely extensible.

column.name: map_feature_id
column.remarks: map_feature_id links to the feature (map) upon which the feature is being localized.

table.name: featureposprop
table.remarks: Property or attribute of a featurepos record.

table.name: featureprop
table.remarks: A feature can have any number of slot-value property tags attached to it. This is an alternative to hardcoding a list of columns in the relational schema, and is completely extensible.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The name of the property/slot is a cvterm. The meaning of the property is defined in that cvterm. Certain property types will only apply to certain feature types (e.g. the anticodon property will only apply to tRNA features) ; the types here come from the sequence feature property ontology.

column.name: value
column.remarks: The value of the property, represented as text. Numeric values are converted to their text representation. This is less efficient than using native database types, but is easier to query.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: Property-Value ordering. Any feature can have multiple values for any particular property type - these are ordered in a list using rank, counting from zero. For properties that are single-valued rather than multi-valued, the default 0 value should be used

table.name: featureprop_pub
table.remarks: Provenance. Any featureprop assignment can optionally be supported by a publication.

table.name: featurerange
table.remarks: In cases where the start and end of a mapped feature is a range, leftendf and rightstartf are populated. leftstartf_id, leftendf_id, rightstartf_id, rightendf_id are the ids of features with respect to which the feature is being mapped. These may be cytological bands.

column.name: featuremap_id
column.remarks: featuremap_id is the id of the feature being mapped.

table.name: genotype
table.remarks: Genetic context. A genotype is defined by a collection of features, mutations, balancers, deficiencies, haplotype blocks, or engineered constructs.

column.name: name
column.remarks: Optional alternative name for a genotype, for display purposes.

column.name: uniquename
column.remarks: The unique name for a genotype; typically derived from the features making up the genotype.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The type_id foreign key links to a controlled vocabulary of library types. Examples of this would be: "cDNA_library" or "genomic_library"

table.name: library_contact
table.remarks: Links contact(s) with a library. Used to indicate a particular person or organization responsible for creation of or that can provide more information on a particular library.

table.name: library_cvterm
table.remarks: The table library_cvterm links a library to controlled vocabularies which describe the library. For instance, there might be a link to the anatomy cv for "head" or "testes" for a head or testes library.

table.name: library_dbxref
table.remarks: Links a library to dbxrefs.

table.name: library_expression
table.remarks: Links a library to expression statements.

table.name: library_expressionprop
table.remarks: Attributes of a library_expression relationship.

table.name: library_feature
table.remarks: library_feature links a library to the clones which are contained in the library. Examples of such linked features might be "cDNA_clone" or "genomic_clone".

table.name: library_featureprop
table.remarks: Attributes of a library_feature relationship.

table.name: library_pub
table.remarks: Attribution for a library.

table.name: library_relationship
table.remarks: Relationships between libraries.

table.name: library_relationship_pub
table.remarks: Provenance of library_relationship.

table.name: library_synonym
table.remarks: Linking table between library and synonym.

column.name: pub_id
column.remarks: The pub_id link is for relating the usage of a given synonym to the publication in which it was used.

column.name: is_current
column.remarks: The is_current bit indicates whether the linked synonym is the current -official- symbol for the linked library.

column.name: is_internal
column.remarks: Typically a synonym exists so that somebody querying the database with an obsolete name can find the object they are looking for under its current name. If the synonym has been used publicly and deliberately (e.g. in a paper), it my also be listed in reports as a synonym. If the synonym was not used deliberately (e.g., there was a typo which went public), then the is_internal bit may be set to "true" so that it is known that the synonym is "internal" and should be queryable but should not be listed in reports as a valid synonym.

table.name: libraryprop
table.remarks: Tag-value properties - follows standard chado model.

table.name: libraryprop_pub
table.remarks: Attribution for libraryprop.

table.name: mageml
table.remarks: This table is for storing extra bits of MAGEml in a denormalized form. More normalization would require many more tables.

table.name: nd_experiment
table.remarks: This is the core table for the natural diversity module, representing each individual assay that is undertaken (this is usually *not* an entire experiment). Each nd_experiment should give rise to a single genotype or phenotype and be described via 1 (or more) protocols. Collections of assays that relate to each other should be linked to the same record in the project table.

table.name: nd_experiment_analysis
table.remarks: An analysis that is used in an experiment

table.name: nd_experiment_dbxref
table.remarks: Cross-reference experiment to accessions, images, etc

table.name: nd_experiment_genotype
table.remarks: Linking table: experiments to the genotypes they produce. There is a one-to-one relationship between an experiment and a genotype since each genotype record should point to one experiment. Add a new experiment_id for each genotype record.

table.name: nd_experiment_phenotype
table.remarks: Linking table: experiments to the phenotypes they produce. There is a one-to-one relationship between an experiment and a phenotype since each phenotype record should point to one experiment. Add a new experiment_id for each phenotype record.

table.name: nd_experiment_project
table.remarks: Used to group together related nd_experiment records. All nd_experiments should be linked to at least one project.

table.name: nd_experiment_protocol
table.remarks: Linking table: experiments to the protocols they involve.

table.name: nd_experiment_pub
table.remarks: Linking nd_experiment(s) to publication(s)

table.name: nd_experiment_stock
table.remarks: Part of a stock or a clone of a stock that is used in an experiment

column.name: stock_id
column.remarks: stock used in the extraction or the corresponding stock for the clone

table.name: nd_experiment_stock_dbxref
table.remarks: Cross-reference experiment_stock to accessions, images, etc

table.name: nd_experiment_stockprop
table.remarks: Property/value associations for experiment_stocks. This table can store the properties such as treatment

column.name: nd_experiment_stock_id
column.remarks: The experiment_stock to which the property applies.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The name of the property as a reference to a controlled vocabulary term.

column.name: value
column.remarks: The value of the property.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: The rank of the property value, if the property has an array of values.

table.name: nd_experimentprop
table.remarks: An nd_experiment can have any number of slot-value property tags attached to it. This is an alternative to hardcoding a list of columns in the relational schema, and is completely extensible. There is a unique constraint, stockprop_c1, for the combination of stock_id, rank, and type_id. Multivalued property-value pairs must be differentiated by rank.

table.name: nd_geolocation
table.remarks: The geo-referencable location of the stock. NOTE: This entity is subject to change as a more general and possibly more OpenGIS-compliant geolocation module may be introduced into Chado.

column.name: description
column.remarks: A textual representation of the location, if this is the original georeference. Optional if the original georeference is available in lat/long coordinates.

column.name: latitude
column.remarks: The decimal latitude coordinate of the georeference, using positive and negative sign to indicate N and S, respectively.

column.name: longitude
column.remarks: The decimal longitude coordinate of the georeference, using positive and negative sign to indicate E and W, respectively.

column.name: geodetic_datum
column.remarks: The geodetic system on which the geo-reference coordinates are based. For geo-references measured between 1984 and 2010, this will typically be WGS84.

column.name: altitude
column.remarks: The altitude (elevation) of the location in meters. If the altitude is only known as a range, this is the average, and altitude_dev will hold half of the width of the range.

table.name: nd_geolocationprop
table.remarks: Property/value associations for geolocations. This table can store the properties such as location and environment

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The name of the property as a reference to a controlled vocabulary term.

column.name: value
column.remarks: The value of the property.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: The rank of the property value, if the property has an array of values.

table.name: nd_protocol
table.remarks: A protocol can be anything that is done as part of the experiment.

column.name: name
column.remarks: The protocol name.

table.name: nd_protocolprop
table.remarks: Property/value associations for protocol.

column.name: nd_protocol_id
column.remarks: The protocol to which the property applies.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The name of the property as a reference to a controlled vocabulary term.

column.name: value
column.remarks: The value of the property.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: The rank of the property value, if the property has an array of values.

table.name: nd_reagent
table.remarks: A reagent such as a primer, an enzyme, an adapter oligo, a linker oligo. Reagents are used in genotyping experiments, or in any other kind of experiment.

column.name: name
column.remarks: The name of the reagent. The name should be unique for a given type.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The type of the reagent, for example linker oligomer, or forward primer.

column.name: feature_id
column.remarks: If the reagent is a primer, the feature that it corresponds to. More generally, the corresponding feature for any reagent that has a sequence that maps to another sequence.

table.name: nd_reagent_relationship
table.remarks: Relationships between reagents. Some reagents form a group. i.e., they are used all together or not at all. Examples are adapter/linker/enzyme experiment reagents.

column.name: subject_reagent_id
column.remarks: The subject reagent in the relationship. In parent/child terminology, the subject is the child. For example, in "linkerA 3prime-overhang-linker enzymeA" linkerA is the subject, 3prime-overhand-linker is the type, and enzymeA is the object.

column.name: object_reagent_id
column.remarks: The object reagent in the relationship. In parent/child terminology, the object is the parent. For example, in "linkerA 3prime-overhang-linker enzymeA" linkerA is the subject, 3prime-overhand-linker is the type, and enzymeA is the object.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The type (or predicate) of the relationship. For example, in "linkerA 3prime-overhang-linker enzymeA" linkerA is the subject, 3prime-overhand-linker is the type, and enzymeA is the object.

table.name: organism
table.remarks: The organismal taxonomic classification. Note that phylogenies are represented using the phylogeny module, and taxonomies can be represented using the cvterm module or the phylogeny module.

column.name: species
column.remarks: A type of organism is always uniquely identified by genus and species. When mapping from the NCBI taxonomy names.dmp file, this column must be used where it is present, as the common_name column is not always unique (e.g. environmental samples). If a particular strain or subspecies is to be represented, this is appended onto the species name. Follows standard NCBI taxonomy pattern.

column.name: infraspecific_name
column.remarks: The scientific name for any taxon below the rank of species. The rank should be specified using the type_id field and the name is provided here.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: A controlled vocabulary term that specifies the organism rank below species. It is used when an infraspecific name is provided. Ideally, the rank should be a valid ICN name such as subspecies, varietas, subvarietas, forma and subforma

table.name: organism_cvterm
table.remarks: organism to cvterm associations. Examples: taxonomic name

column.name: rank
column.remarks: Property-Value ordering. Any organism_cvterm can have multiple values for any particular property type - these are ordered in a list using rank, counting from zero. For properties that are single-valued rather than multi-valued, the default 0 value should be used

table.name: organism_cvtermprop
table.remarks: Extensible properties for organism to cvterm associations. Examples: qualifiers

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The name of the property/slot is a cvterm. The meaning of the property is defined in that cvterm.

column.name: value
column.remarks: The value of the property, represented as text. Numeric values are converted to their text representation. This is less efficient than using native database types, but is easier to query.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: Property-Value ordering. Any organism_cvterm can have multiple values for any particular property type - these are ordered in a list using rank, counting from zero. For properties that are single-valued rather than multi-valued, the default 0 value should be used

table.name: organism_dbxref
table.remarks: Links an organism to a dbxref.

table.name: organism_pub
table.remarks: Attribution for organism.

table.name: organism_relationship
table.remarks: Specifies relationships between organisms that are not taxonomic. For example, in breeding, relationships such as "sterile_with", "incompatible_with", or "fertile_with" would be appropriate. Taxonomic relatinoships should be housed in the phylogeny tables.

table.name: organismprop
table.remarks: Tag-value properties - follows standard chado model.

table.name: organismprop_pub
table.remarks: Attribution for organismprop.

table.name: phendesc
table.remarks: A summary of a _set_ of phenotypic statements for any one gcontext made in any one publication.

table.name: phenotype
table.remarks: A phenotypic statement, or a single atomic phenotypic observation, is a controlled sentence describing observable effects of non-wild type function. E.g. Obs=eye, attribute=color, cvalue=red.

column.name: observable_id
column.remarks: The entity: e.g. anatomy_part, biological_process.

column.name: attr_id
column.remarks: Phenotypic attribute (quality, property, attribute, character) - drawn from PATO.

column.name: value
column.remarks: Value of attribute - unconstrained free text. Used only if cvalue_id is not appropriate.

column.name: cvalue_id
column.remarks: Phenotype attribute value (state).

column.name: assay_id
column.remarks: Evidence type.

table.name: phenotype_comparison
table.remarks: Comparison of phenotypes e.g., genotype1/environment1/phenotype1 "non-suppressible" with respect to genotype2/environment2/phenotype2.

table.name: phenotype_cvterm
table.remarks: phenotype to cvterm associations.

table.name: phenotypeprop
table.remarks: A phenotype can have any number of slot-value property tags attached to it. This is an alternative to hardcoding a list of columns in the relational schema, and is completely extensible. There is a unique constraint, phenotypeprop_c1, for the combination of phenotype_id, rank, and type_id. Multivalued property-value pairs must be differentiated by rank.

table.name: phenstatement
table.remarks: Phenotypes are things like "larval lethal". Phenstatements are things like "dpp-1 is recessive larval lethal". So essentially phenstatement is a linking table expressing the relationship between genotype, environment, and phenotype.

table.name: phylonode
table.remarks: This is the most pervasive element in the phylogeny module, cataloging the "phylonodes" of tree graphs. Edges are implied by the parent_phylonode_id reflexive closure. For all nodes in a nested set implementation the left and right index will be *between* the parents left and right indexes.

column.name: parent_phylonode_id
column.remarks: Root phylonode can have null parent_phylonode_id value.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: Type: e.g. root, interior, leaf.

column.name: feature_id
column.remarks: Phylonodes can have optional features attached to them e.g. a protein or nucleotide sequence usually attached to a leaf of the phylotree for non-leaf nodes, the feature may be a feature that is an instance of SO:match; this feature is the alignment of all leaf features beneath it.

table.name: phylonode_dbxref
table.remarks: For example, for orthology, paralogy group identifiers; could also be used for NCBI taxonomy; for sequences, refer to phylonode_feature, feature associated dbxrefs.

table.name: phylonode_organism
table.remarks: This linking table should only be used for nodes in taxonomy trees; it provides a mapping between the node and an organism. One node can have zero or one organisms, one organism can have zero or more nodes (although typically it should only have one in the standard NCBI taxonomy tree).

column.name: phylonode_id
column.remarks: One phylonode cannot refer to >1 organism.

table.name: phylonode_relationship
table.remarks: This is for relationships that are not strictly hierarchical; for example, horizontal gene transfer. Most phylogenetic trees are strictly hierarchical, nevertheless it is here for completeness.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: type_id could designate phylonode hierarchy relationships, for example: species taxonomy (kingdom, order, family, genus, species), "ortholog/paralog", "fold/superfold", etc.

table.name: phylotree
table.remarks: Global anchor for phylogenetic tree.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: Type: protein, nucleotide, taxonomy, for example. The type should be any SO type, or "taxonomy".

table.name: phylotree_pub
table.remarks: Tracks citations global to the tree e.g. multiple sequence alignment supporting tree construction.

table.name: phylotreeprop
table.remarks: A phylotree can have any number of slot-value property tags attached to it. This is an alternative to hardcoding a list of columns in the relational schema, and is completely extensible.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The name of the property/slot is a cvterm. The meaning of the property is defined in that cvterm.

column.name: value
column.remarks: The value of the property, represented as text. Numeric values are converted to their text representation. This is less efficient than using native database types, but is easier to query.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: Property-Value ordering. Any phylotree can have multiple values for any particular property type these are ordered in a list using rank, counting from zero. For properties that are single-valued rather than multi-valued, the default 0 value should be used

table.name: project
table.remarks: Standard Chado flexible property table for projects.

table.name: project_analysis
table.remarks: Links an analysis to a project that may contain multiple analyses. The rank column can be used to specify a simple ordering in which analyses were executed.

table.name: project_contact
table.remarks: Linking table for associating projects and contacts.

table.name: project_dbxref
table.remarks: project_dbxref links a project to dbxrefs.

column.name: is_current
column.remarks: The is_current boolean indicates whether the linked dbxref is the current -official- dbxref for the linked project.

table.name: project_feature
table.remarks: This table is intended associate records in the feature table with a project.

table.name: project_pub
table.remarks: Linking table for associating projects and publications.

table.name: project_relationship
table.remarks: Linking table for relating projects to each other. For example, a given project could be composed of several smaller subprojects

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The cvterm type of the relationship being stated, such as "part of".

table.name: project_stock
table.remarks: This table is intended associate records in the stock table with a project.

table.name: protocol
table.remarks: Procedural notes on how data was prepared and processed.

table.name: protocolparam
table.remarks: Parameters related to a protocol. For example, if the protocol is a soak, this might include attributes of bath temperature and duration.

table.name: pub
table.remarks: A documented provenance artefact - publications, documents, personal communication.

column.name: title
column.remarks: Descriptive general heading.

column.name: volumetitle
column.remarks: Title of part if one of a series.

column.name: series_name
column.remarks: Full name of (journal) series.

column.name: pages
column.remarks: Page number range[s], e.g. 457--459, viii + 664pp, lv--lvii.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The type of the publication (book, journal, poem, graffiti, etc). Uses pub cv.

table.name: pub_dbxref
table.remarks: Handle links to repositories, e.g. Pubmed, Biosis, zoorec, OCLC, Medline, ISSN, coden...

table.name: pub_relationship
table.remarks: Handle relationships between publications, e.g. when one publication makes others obsolete, when one publication contains errata with respect to other publication(s), or when one publication also appears in another pub.

table.name: pubauthor
table.remarks: An author for a publication. Note the denormalisation (hence lack of _ in table name) - this is deliberate as it is in general too hard to assign IDs to authors.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: Order of author in author list for this pub - order is important.

column.name: editor
column.remarks: Indicates whether the author is an editor for linked publication. Note: this is a boolean field but does not follow the normal chado convention for naming booleans.

column.name: givennames
column.remarks: First name, initials

column.name: suffix
column.remarks: Jr., Sr., etc

table.name: pubauthor_contact
table.remarks: An author on a publication may have a corresponding entry in the contact table and this table can link the two.

table.name: pubprop
table.remarks: Property-value pairs for a pub. Follows standard chado pattern.

table.name: quantification
table.remarks: Quantification is the transformation of an image acquisition to numeric data. This typically involves statistical procedures.

table.name: quantification_relationship
table.remarks: There may be multiple rounds of quantification, this allows us to keep an audit trail of what values went where.

table.name: quantificationprop
table.remarks: Extra quantification properties that are not accounted for in quantification.

table.name: stock
table.remarks: Any stock can be globally identified by the combination of organism, uniquename and stock type. A stock is the physical entities, either living or preserved, held by collections. Stocks belong to a collection; they have IDs, type, organism, description and may have a genotype.

column.name: dbxref_id
column.remarks: The dbxref_id is an optional primary stable identifier for this stock. Secondary indentifiers and external dbxrefs go in table: stock_dbxref.

column.name: organism_id
column.remarks: The organism_id is the organism to which the stock belongs. This column should only be left blank if the organism cannot be determined.

column.name: name
column.remarks: The name is a human-readable local name for a stock.

column.name: description
column.remarks: The description is the genetic description provided in the stock list.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The type_id foreign key links to a controlled vocabulary of stock types. The would include living stock, genomic DNA, preserved specimen. Secondary cvterms for stocks would go in stock_cvterm.

table.name: stock_cvterm
table.remarks: stock_cvterm links a stock to cvterms. This is for secondary cvterms; primary cvterms should use stock.type_id.

table.name: stock_cvtermprop
table.remarks: Extensible properties for stock to cvterm associations. Examples: GO evidence codes; qualifiers; metadata such as the date on which the entry was curated and the source of the association. See the stockprop table for meanings of type_id, value and rank.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The name of the property/slot is a cvterm. The meaning of the property is defined in that cvterm. cvterms may come from the OBO evidence code cv.

column.name: value
column.remarks: The value of the property, represented as text. Numeric values are converted to their text representation. This is less efficient than using native database types, but is easier to query.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: Property-Value ordering. Any stock_cvterm can have multiple values for any particular property type - these are ordered in a list using rank, counting from zero. For properties that are single-valued rather than multi-valued, the default 0 value should be used.

table.name: stock_dbxref
table.remarks: stock_dbxref links a stock to dbxrefs. This is for secondary identifiers; primary identifiers should use stock.dbxref_id.

column.name: is_current
column.remarks: The is_current boolean indicates whether the linked dbxref is the current -official- dbxref for the linked stock.

table.name: stock_dbxrefprop
table.remarks: A stock_dbxref can have any number of slot-value property tags attached to it. This is useful for storing properties related to dbxref annotations of stocks, such as evidence codes, and references, and metadata, such as create/modify dates. This is an alternative to hardcoding a list of columns in the relational schema, and is completely extensible. There is a unique constraint, stock_dbxrefprop_c1, for the combination of stock_dbxref_id, rank, and type_id. Multivalued property-value pairs must be differentiated by rank.

table.name: stock_feature
table.remarks: Links a stock to a feature.

table.name: stock_featuremap
table.remarks: Links a featuremap to a stock.

table.name: stock_genotype
table.remarks: Simple table linking a stock to a genotype. Features with genotypes can be linked to stocks thru feature_genotype -> genotype -> stock_genotype -> stock.

table.name: stock_library
table.remarks: Links a stock with a library.

table.name: stock_pub
table.remarks: Provenance. Linking table between stocks and, for example, a stocklist computer file.

column.name: subject_id
column.remarks: stock_relationship.subject_id is the subject of the subj-predicate-obj sentence. This is typically the substock.

column.name: object_id
column.remarks: stock_relationship.object_id is the object of the subj-predicate-obj sentence. This is typically the container stock.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: stock_relationship.type_id is relationship type between subject and object. This is a cvterm, typically from the OBO relationship ontology, although other relationship types are allowed.

column.name: value
column.remarks: stock_relationship.value is for additional notes or comments.

column.name: rank
column.remarks: stock_relationship.rank is the ordering of subject stocks with respect to the object stock may be important where rank is used to order these; starts from zero.

table.name: stock_relationship_cvterm
table.remarks: For germplasm maintenance and pedigree data, stock_relationship. type_id will record cvterms such as "is a female parent of", "a parent for mutation", "is a group_id of", "is a source_id of", etc The cvterms for higher categories such as "generative", "derivative" or "maintenance" can be stored in table stock_relationship_cvterm

table.name: stock_relationship_pub
table.remarks: Provenance. Attach optional evidence to a stock_relationship in the form of a publication.

table.name: stockcollection
table.remarks: The lab or stock center distributing the stocks in their collection.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: type_id is the collection type cv.

column.name: contact_id
column.remarks: contact_id links to the contact information for the collection.

column.name: name
column.remarks: name is the collection.

column.name: uniquename
column.remarks: uniqename is the value of the collection cv.

table.name: stockcollection_db
table.remarks: Stock collections may be respresented by an external online database. This table associates a stock collection with a database where its member stocks can be found. Individual stock that are part of this collction should have entries in the stock_dbxref table with the same db_id record

table.name: stockcollection_stock
table.remarks: stockcollection_stock links a stock collection to the stocks which are contained in the collection.

table.name: stockcollectionprop

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: The cv for the type_id is "stockcollection property type".

table.name: stockprop
table.remarks: A stock can have any number of slot-value property tags attached to it. This is an alternative to hardcoding a list of columns in the relational schema, and is completely extensible. There is a unique constraint, stockprop_c1, for the combination of stock_id, rank, and type_id. Multivalued property-value pairs must be differentiated by rank.

table.name: stockprop_pub
table.remarks: Provenance. Any stockprop assignment can optionally be supported by a publication.

table.name: synonym
table.remarks: A synonym for a feature. One feature can have multiple synonyms, and the same synonym can apply to multiple features.

column.name: name
column.remarks: The synonym itself. Should be human-readable machine-searchable ascii text.

column.name: type_id
column.remarks: Types would be symbol and fullname for now.

column.name: synonym_sgml
column.remarks: The fully specified synonym, with any non-ascii characters encoded in SGML.

table.name: treatment
table.remarks: A biomaterial may undergo multiple treatments. Examples of treatments: apoxia, fluorophore and biotin labeling.
